title: 105_s380
content: The Act may be cited as the "Durbin-Kennedy Empire State Building Counter-Terrorism Act of 1997." It includes provisions related to firearms. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code is amended to address aliens illegally or unlawfully in the United States or those admitted under a nonimmigrant visa. Section 922 of title 18, United States Code is amended to address aliens illegally or unlawfully in the United States or those admitted under a nonimmigrant visa. The amendment includes provisions relating to aliens admitted under nonimmigrant visas. Provisions relating to aliens admitted under nonimmigrant visas include exceptions for those admitted for lawful hunting or sporting purposes. Exceptions for aliens admitted under nonimmigrant visas include those for lawful hunting or sporting purposes, official representatives of foreign governments accredited to the US, designated officials or visitors by the Department of State, and foreign law enforcement officers. Foreign law enforcement officers of friendly foreign governments entering the United States on official business may receive a waiver from certain visa requirements by submitting a petition to the Attorney General. Foreign law enforcement officers entering the US on official business can petition the Attorney General to acquire firearms or ammunition, provided they have resided in the US for at least 180 days and have authorization from their embassy or consulate. The Attorney General must approve the petition if it meets the requirements. The Attorney General shall approve a petition if waiving certain requirements is in the interests of justice and does not jeopardize public safety.
